newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ sends back 33 Thais deemed illegal workers.
newsitem.headline: NZ sends back 33 Thais deemed illegal workers.

text.p: New Zealand's Immigration Service on Friday sent back a group of 33 Thais believed to be trying to enter the country to seek work, officials said.
The seven women and 26 men arrived at Wellington airport together on a flight from Bangkok via Sydney, Australia, on Thursday afternoon but were stopped by immigration officers.
"It became clear they were not genuine visitors, and the Immigration Service believed they were planning to work illegally in New Zealand," immigration spokeswoman Ann Howarth told Reuters.
"It is believed to be the largest group (of any nationality) turned back," she said, adding that so far this year about 230 Thais had been refused entry.
Data for other nationalities was not immediately available, but Howarth said such occurences "happen every day -- though not usually in such large numbers".

Under New Zealand's entry rules, citizens of about 30 countries do not need to have a visa if they intend to only make a short visit. Thai nationals do not need to apply for a visa and are issued visitor permits on arrival.
The group of Thais was moved to the larger Auckland airport and, after spending the night in the terminal there, left on a direct flight back to Thailand without incident, Howarth said.
